passages.text: Singtel is on- track to deliver on its Singtel28 mid- term plan (first announced in May 2024), where management highlighted the core EBIT improvement and its recent move to raise the asset recycling target while introducing a new \(\) 2\$ bn buyback program. They noted positive investor feedback on Optus' recovery, Airtel's momentum, the group's clear shareholder return strategy, and emerging Singapore mobile competition.
Singtel reiterated its FY26 guidance and mid- term ROIC targets (double digits for the group, high single digits for Optus).

Highlights across operating companies "opcos" include: Singtel Singapore's launch of \(5G+\) network for premium customers as a way to differentiate vs peers, Optus' revenue uplift from recent price hikes and upcoming revenue/cost synergies as its network sharing with TPG takes effect, growth engines NCS and Infraco \(>400MW\) of Al- ready data center capacity in the pipeline) doubling down on Al.

The group is adopting a holistic approach to Al, where its opcos in Singapore and Australia will adopt Al across all functions (improving productivity, customer experience, and cost efficiency), while NCS will develop Al solutions for enterprises, with Infraco as infrastructure enabler for both internal and external customers.

Singtel aims to continue delivering sustainable dividend growth through operating performance and active capital management. While value realization dividend "VRD" (funded by asset recycling) is set to continue a few more years, management is focusing on growing the portion from core DPS as profitability improves across opcos. On asset recycling ( \(\) 4b\(out of the\) \ \(59b\) target already completed, remainder to be done in the next few years), management looks at all options (e.g. real estate, infrastructure beyond monetizing associate stakes); also complimented by external funding partners (e.g. KKR partnership).

Overall, Singtel sees its strengths in having resilient cash flows (no direct impact from tariffs) and healthy balance sheet (strong interest coverage, low fixed rate debt), supporting its ability to generate sustainable dividend growth.

As the second largest telco operator in Australia, Optus currently has c. \(31\%\) mobile customer share across consumer and enterprise segments (as of 31 Dec 2024), with \(98.5\%\) network coverage of the Australian population.

Management sees continued population growth (including a sizable immigrant population) as supportive towards industry growth, although consumer wallet share on telco has declined over the past decade given intense competition - with the industry currently operating at \(32 - 36\%\) EBITDA margins, \(6 - 8\%\) ROIC.

Optus' strategy is to prioritize ROIC repair (high single digits target, which is the key lever to Singtel group's double digits mid- term target), rebuild trust and reputation, and modernise infrastructure.
While rising postpaid ARPU (industry repair within tier 1 operators) has provided
revenue uplift, management noted intensifying tier 2 competition as a headwind. Optus intends to remain focused on its tier 1 proposition, and sees room for further price uplift.
Management expects Optus' capex/sales ratio to decline over time from the current \(17\%\) .

Key highlight for its Singapore opco (consumer and enterprise combined) has been the EBIT and EBITDA turnaround in FY25 following the decline seen in FY23- 24, with the opco's latest EBITDA margin of \(39\%\) placing it at the top end among leading telco operators in developed markets (ranging from \(37\%\) in Australia to \(28\%\) in Japan, per management). While revenue performance remains muted on the drag from the competitive consumer segment (mainly mobile, increasingly seen in broadband), management sees tailwinds from potential industry consolidation, while the enterprise unit continues to deliver quality growth.
Its FY28 targets include: return to revenue growth with EBITDA margin to sustain at \(>35\%\) , and low teens capex/revenue ratio.

Regardless of consolidation outcome, Singtel intends to execute on its AI transformation plan and customer pyramid strategy - using the analogy of airlines' business class, Singtel is focusing more on high value customers ( \(>\) 40 ARPU) that can provide outsized revenue contribution. This is reflected by its new \(5G+\) where Singtel is the first telco globally to perform network slicing for consumers, aimed to provide superior speeds during congested periods. To support this, Singtel has also acquired 4 lots of 700MHz low band spectrum, all of which have been deployed for 5G.

Management sees uncertainty on how consolidation between the 4th and 3rd largest players (vs more commonly seen 2nd and 3rd) may play out, with added complexity from M1's existing JV with Starhub (of which Simba is not a part of), though Singtel remains focused on its own strategy. \*Refer to our real estate team's note on Keppel's proposed divestment of M1.

Infraco consists of 5 product units that management views as part of an interconnected tech stack which will help Singtel capture the AI opportunity: submarine cables, satellites, Nxera (data center), RE:AI (software GPUaaS and AlaaS), Paragon (AI orchestration platform).

Management expects Nxera to continue driving the unit's momentum: now already operational in 4 countries with 200MW of capacity, with another 200MW in the pipeline. By region, the next data centers to start operating include: DC Tuas (58MW) and Indonesia (18MW) by 1Q26, Malaysia (64MW) by 4Q26, Thailand phase 2 (38MW) by 2Q27. Outside of ASEAN, Nxera has also entered a strategic partnership with Hitachi to build data centers in Japan.

NCS is a leading IT service player divided into 3 go- to- market business units: Gov+ (public service, defense, homeland security), Telco+ (telco, media, tech), Enterprise (across various sectors). NCS has been executing on its triple axis growth strategy: expanding into new geographies (beyond Singapore to China, Australia, other APAC), industries (beyond government/public sector), and services (more digital/Al- focused).

After completing phase 1 of its strategy in FY25 (laying the foundation by setting up the 3 units, initial expansion into Australia and China), NCS is now entering phase 2 where it's aiming to become a Pan- APAC tech services leader - focus areas include: AI innovation (helping its clients undergo AI transformations, explore partnerships with global tech players), margin expansion (by shifting to higher margin services/more complex work, offshoring to leverage labour arbitrage).

While intense mobile competition and ongoing decline in legacy revenues, exacerbated by the weak consumer spending backdrop in Indonesia have been weighing on Telkomsel's results; management has started seeing market repair in the past 2 months, with higher government spending since June to support economic recovery.

Instead of price war, Telkomsel aims to compete by offering a differentiated customer experience. This includes simplifying its brand portfolio: focusing on Simpati for prepaid, byU for the youth segment, high value postpaid (vs Telkomsel Lite seen as a temporary fighting brand to retain customers). Notably, Telkomsel has initiated price hikes since June, with peers having followed suit.
Telkomsel currently covers 5G in 56 cities (management noted regional affordability levels as a consideration when expanding), with 4G at \(>97\%\) population coverage.
Management expects 5G auction (700MHz + 2.6GHz bands) to take place early next year, though it doesn't expect an increase in its capex/revenue ratio (14- 15%).

Turning to broadband, management attributed muted performance to competition (mainly within lower end, outer regions), though they intend to drive growth through: 1) upgrading existing customers to higher speed plans, 2) pushing greenfield home passes (with household broadband penetration in Indonesia still at 15%), especially in less competitive regions outside Java.
Legacy units currently contribute 9% of revenue, with management expecting this to stabilize at 4- 5% in 1.5 years.

Despite growing macro headwinds in Thailand (weaker consumer, political instability), ongoing industry rationalization continues to provide support - following a strong 1H25 which exceeded expectations, AIS has revised up its FY25 guidance though this implies a lower 2H vs what was achieved in 1H given ongoing macro uncertainty.

While management expects the duopoly industry structure to continue, AIS aims to differentiate through network quality (through spectrum planning, strategic tower/site locations, while ensuring reliability) and value- added services, and focus on high value customers (with its ARPU now \(>B t600\) ).

Future growth to mainly come from ARPU uplift (on price repair, 5G upgrades): though management is conscious of the consumer spending environment when it comes to considering price hikes. Conversely, there's limited room for net adds given mobile penetration that is already \(140\%\) in Thailand.
On broadband, AIS- 3BB integration is on- track with management targeting unified operations by 2026. Beyond the top 2 operators, management views the \(
(higher income/CBD areas with more postpaid users) vs buy/lease others' capacity (lower end).

We believe Buy- rated Singtel remains a core telco holding in Asia given its strong positioning across multiple markets and business lines, alongside its positioning into new growth areas like digital banks/fintech etc, and attractive valuations.

I, Pang Vittayaamuyakoon, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect my personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. I also certify that no part of my compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FC and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.
Advanced Info Service PCL (Neutral, Bt299.00), Bharti Airtel (Buy, Rs1,881.20), Reliance Industries (Buy, Rs1,387.65) and Telekomunikasi Indonesia (Buy, Rp3,180)

The rating(s) for Singapore Telecommunications is/are relative to the other companies in its/their coverage universe: Advanced Info Service PCL, Grab, PT GoTo GoJek Tokopedia, Sea Ltd., Singapore Telecommunications, StarHub, Telekomunikasi Indonesia, True Corp.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
